cility.   The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with its LEPC and local fire department.  

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at this Facility.

CONCLUSION

The PSM/RMP implemented by the Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The PSM/RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or makes changes to the process. 

NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 8 of the standard RMP produced by EPAs RMP Submit Program are not applicable to this Facility.

ies with the Cargo Truck Operator; connecting the Cargo Truck to the MPR; opening valves and transferring anhydrous ammonia from the Cargo Truck to the MPR; blending the APP liquid fertilizer; closing the valves and disconnecting from the Cargo Truck; and releasing the Cargo Truck back to the Cargo Truck owner/operator.  

OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst case and alternative case offsite consequence analyses were completed for both covered processes. The worst case release scenario assumes that all the content in the largest vessel (i.e. a 10,600-gallon Cargo Truck) is released over a 10-minute period   The release scenario consists of the Cargo Truck being punctured on the side at the ground level and the release is modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.

The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario assumes that a 2-inch liquid transfer hose is severed during the blending process.  The alternative scenario for the Fertilizer Blending covered process considers active mitigation of the safety equipment (i.e. excess flow valve or remote actuated emergency shutoff valve on the Cargo Truck; and remote actuated emergency shutoff valves on the MPR), and operating procedures that the Facility and Contractor implement to safeguard against ammonia releases from transfer operations.

ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Fertilizer & Logistics Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Fertilizer & Logistics Manager is assisted by other Facility staff, as directed.  The Fertilizer & Logistics Manager is responsible for ensuring that Facility Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Accident Prevention Program elements.  The Fertilizer & Logistics Manager is responsible for managing the Contractor in accordance with the Facility PSM/RMP Contractor management program.  The Contractor is responsible for training its personnel in the implementation of its OSHA PSM.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC (HAE) is submitting this electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act § 112(r) as codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) at 29 CFR § 1910.119 and by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR §68.  The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to operations at this Facility.  This electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident, and to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.

PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP

HAE recently acquired this Facility.  Prior to acquisition, the prior owner/operator De-Registered this process.  HAE wants to operate this process so it is resubmitting the Facility EPA registration.  All accident prevention elements have been developed and reviewed.

FACILITY

The operations at this Facility consist of agricultural chemical storage and handling, blending, retail sale and distribution.  The covered processes operated at this Facility include:

o	Covered Process 1: Fertilizer Blending (Ammonium Polyphosphate)

The Facility coordinates delivery of anhydrous ammonia by Cargo Truck and hires a Contactor (A.K.A. Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor  IFRC) to transfer and blend anhydrous ammonia with super phosphoric acid and water to make ammonium polyphosphate (APP) fertilizer.  The APP liquid fertilizer is blended in a Mobile Pipe Reactor (MPR) that is owned and operated by the Contractor.  The APP liquid fertilizer is not subject to the PSM/RMP rules.

The Cargo Truck Owner/Operator is responsible for: transporting anhydrous ammonia to the Facility and staging the Cargo Truck.  The Cargo Truck remains connected to the mode of transportation (i.e. Tractor/Truck) and is considered to be in a status of incident to transportation.
